case_name: Writ Petition Nos 446 of 1971 and 86 of 1972, Civil Appeals Nos. 1319 and 1320 of 1968

facts.text: Writ Petition Nos. 446 of 1971 and 86 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition Nos 446 of 1971 and 86 of 1972.  Under Art. 32 of the Constitution for the enforcement of fundamental rights .

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1319 and 1320 of 1968 from Judgment and Order dated 22nd March 1968 of Delhi High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 798-D and 800-D of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1319 and 1320 of 1968. From the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd March, 1968 of the Delhi High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 798-D and 800-D of 1966.

facts.text: Searches and seizures conducted under section 132 of Income-tax Act, 1961 in all four cases, seizing account books, documents, and in Writ Petitions also cash, jewelry and valuables.

anchor.surface_text: It is sufficient to state that in all these cases articles companysisting of account books and documents and in the Writ Petitions, also cash, jewelry and other valuables, were seized by the Income-tax authorities purporting to act under the, authorisation for search and seizure issued under section 132 of the Act.

facts.text: Constitutional challenge to sub-sections 1 and 5 of section 132 and rule 112A as violative of Articles 14, 19(1)(f)(g) and 31.

anchor.surface_text: Broadly speaking the companystitutional challenge is directed against sub-sections  1  and, 5  of section 132 of the Act and incidentally also against rule 112A on the ground that these provisions are violative of the fundamental rights guaranteed by Articles 14, 19 1   f   g  and 31 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Pooran Mal's residence at 12A Kamla Nagar, Delhi and business premises at A.14/16 Jamuna Bhavan, Asaf Ali Road, New Delhi searched on 15th and 16th October 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Pooran Mal is a partner in a number of firms- some of them doing business in Bombay and some in Delhi. His permanent residence is 12A Kamla Nagar, Delhi. His business premises in Delhi are A.14/16 Jamuna Bhavan, Asaf Ali Road, New Delhi. It would appear that on an authorisation issued by the Director of Inspection, his residence and business premises in Delhi were searched on 15th and 16th October, 1971.

facts.text: Pooran Mal's premises in Bombay searched on 15th October 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On the 15th his premises in Bombay were also searched and at that time it appears. the petitioner was present in Bombay.

facts.text: Jewelry worth Rs. 37,043 seized from Pooran Mal's residence.

anchor.surface_text: It is number denied that companysiderable jewelry was seized. The jewelry seized in the house was worth Rs. 37,043/-

facts.text: Cash amounting to about Rs. 61,000 seized from Pooran Mal's business premises.

anchor.surface_text: The search in the business premises was made when a number of persons who usually worked there were present. Books of account, documents, some jewelry and a large amount of cash amounting to about Rs. 61,000/- were seized.

facts.text: 84 silver bars seized from Laxmi Commercial Bank and 30 from Punjab National Bank, value nearly 18 lakhs, in connection with Pooran Mal.

anchor.surface_text: On 16.10 there was a search in the Branch Offices of Laxmi Commercial Bank and the Punjab National Bank. 84 Silver bars were seized from Laxmi Commercial Bank and 30 silver bars were seized from the Punjab National Bank. The value of these silver bars companyes to nearly 18 lakhs.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer made order dated 12-1-1972 under section 132(5) retaining seized assets of Pooran Mal except ornaments declared in Wealth Tax Return.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Income-tax Officer made a summary enquiry as required by section 132 5  after issuing numberice to the petitioner and his order dated 12-1-1972 shows, of companyrse prima facie, that all the assets which had been seized in the house, the business premises and the banks, except for the value of the ornaments declared by Mrs. Sharda Devi in her Wealth Tax Return, had to be retained

facts.text: Ganeriwala's residence at 1, Raj Narain Road, Civil Lines, Delhi and business at 1 Krishna Motor Market, Kashmiri Gate, Delhi searched on 8-10-1971.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Ganeriwala is a businessman. His residence is 1, Raj Narain Road, Civil Lines, Delhi and he runs a family business in Automobile parts in the name of Ganeriwala Trading Company. The business is at number 1 Krishna Motor Market, Kashimiri Gate, Delhi. ... on 8-101971 his residential house and also the business premises were searched

facts.text: No cash, bullion, ornaments or jewelry found in Ganeriwala search; documents and books of account seized.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner stated that though the raiding party made a very detailed search, they did. number companye across any companycealed incomemash of bullion, ornaments or jewelry. ... documents and books of account were seized.

facts.text: Delhi High Court dismissed Writ Petitions Nos. 798-D and 800-D of 1966 on or before 22 March 1968, documents returned, denied writ of prohibition on use of seized info.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd March, 1968 of the Delhi High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 798-D and 800-D of 1966. ... The High Court has number done so. The relief claimed in those petitions in the High Court was for the, return of the account books and documents which had been seized and it would appear from the record that before the High Court disposed of that matters, the account books and documents had been already returned.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds sections 132(1), 132(5), 132A and rule 112A constitutional, not violative of Articles 14, 19(1)(f)(g), 31.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions, therefore, relating to search and seizure in section 132 and rule 12 cannot be regarded as violative of articles 19 f  and  g . ... We are number, therefore, inclined to hold that the restrictions placed by any of the provisions of section 132, 132A or rule 112A are unreasonable restrictions on the freedoms under section 19 1   f   g .

facts.text: Searches in all cases conducted legally, no illegality or mala fides found by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, therefore, we are number inclined to hold that the search and seizure in this Writ Petition was vitiated by any illegality. ... The search and seizure, therefore, impugned in this Writ Petition cannot be regarded as illegal.

facts.text: Pooran Mal partner in firms doing business in Bombay and Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Pooran Mal is a partner in a number of firms- some of them doing business in Bombay and some in Delhi.

facts.text: Ganeriwala runs Ganeriwala Trading Company in automobile parts.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Ganeriwala is a businessman. ... he runs a family business in Automobile parts in the name of Ganeriwala Trading Company.

facts.text: Authorisation for Pooran Mal search issued by Director of Inspection.

anchor.surface_text: It would appear that on an authorisation issued by the Director of Inspection, his residence and business premises in Delhi were searched

facts.text: Petitioner Pooran Mal's assessments pending for 1967-68, no returns for 1968-69 or later.

anchor.surface_text: Assessment for the year 1967-68 is still pending and numberreturn has been filed for the year 1968-69 or for later years.

facts.text: Ganeriwala constructed huge godown of 6700 sq ft near residence using unaccounted money.

anchor.surface_text: the search and seizure had been ordered because the petitioner had recently companystructed a huge godown near his residential premises with the floor area of approximately 6700 sq ft. on which a large investment was estimated to have been made from income which had number been disclosed

issues.text: Whether sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 132 of the Income-tax Act, 1961 and rule 112A are violative of Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: authorisation for search and seizure issued under section 132 of the Act. Broadly speaking the constitutional challenge is directed against sub-sections  1  and, 5  of section 132 of the Act and incidentally also against rule 112A on the ground that these provisions are violative of the fundamental rights guaranteed by Articles 14, 19 1   f   g  and 31 of the

issues.text: Whether sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 132 of the Income-tax Act, 1961 and rule 112A are violative of Article 14 of the Constitution on grounds of discrimination between tax evaders?

anchor.surface_text: violative of the fundamental right under Article 14 on the ground  1  that they make unjust discrimination between evaders of tax who are believed to be in possession of undisclosed income from those who are not, and  2  that although all evaders are liable to be proceeded against under section 147 of the Act, yet only some of them who are found in possession

issues.text: Whether sub-section (5) of section 132 of the Income-tax Act, 1961 is confiscatory and violative of Article 31 of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: these provisions are violative of the fundamental rights guaranteed by Articles 14, 19 1   f   g  and 31 of the Constitution. The non-constitutional grounds of challenge are based upon allegations to the effect that the search and seizure were not in accordance with section 132 read with Rule 112.

issues.text: Whether the searches and seizures were conducted in accordance with section 132 read with rule 112 of the Income-tax Rules?

anchor.surface_text: The non-constitutional grounds of challenge are based upon allegations to the effect that the search and seizure were not in accordance with section 132 read with Rule 112. This challenge will have to be considered in the background of the facts of the individual cases.

issues.text: Whether evidence obtained as a result of an illegal search and seizure is admissible in proceedings under the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: permits relevancy as the only test of admissibility of evidence  See section 5 of the Act  and, secondly, that Act or any other similar law in force does not exclude relevant evidence, on the ground that it was obtained under an illegal search or seizure

issues.text: Whether the Director of Inspection or Commissioner can form a reasonable belief under section 132(1)(b) that a person will not produce documents if summoned?

anchor.surface_text: A subsidiary point relating to the entertainment of reasonable belief under section 132 was also raised... But to say that the authority can also have reason to believe that if a requisition is made the person concerned will not in future produce the document is, according to Mr. Karkhanis, a conclusion which is impossible to draw on any conceivable facts.

issues.text: Whether a writ of prohibition can be issued restraining the use of information gathered from illegal search and seizure?

anchor.surface_text: the only question is whether the information gathered as a result of such search and seizure could be used in evidence if it be held that the search and seizure was illegal... We have held that such information can be used.

issues.text: Whether the specific searches and seizures in Writ Petition No. 446 of 1971 and Writ Petition No. 86 of 1972 were illegal or vitiated by mala fides?

holdings.text: The provisions relating to search and seizure in section 132 and rule 112 cannot be regarded as violative of articles 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: The provisions, therefore, relating to search and seizure in section 132 and rule 12 cannot be regarded as violative of articles 19 f  and  g . A minor point was urged in support of the above contention that section 132 contains provisions which are likely to affect even innocent persons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adequate inbuilt safeguards in high officers' authorization, reason to believe, CrPC applicability, summary enquiry under s132(5), precedents like MP Sharma and sales tax case; necessary to prevent tax evasion.

holdings.text: Sections 132(1) and (5) are not violative of Article 14 as there is no unjust discrimination between tax evaders.

anchor.surface_text: We find nosubstance in this argument. All evaders of tax can be proceeded against under section 132. Only in some cases the, search may be useful in others it may not be.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Different situations for evaders with/without seizable undisclosed assets; s132 available to all but useful only where assets found; no different assessment procedure.

holdings.text: Section 132(5) is not confiscatory and does not violate Article 31.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that section 132 5  is confiscatory in its effect has also noforce. It must be remembered that the object of this provision is to expedite the return of the seized assets after retaining what is due by way of tax to Government

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisional retention after summary enquiry; balance returned immediately or with interest under s132A; not substitute for regular assessment.

holdings.text: Evidence obtained as a result of illegal search and seizure is admissible if relevant under Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: Now, if the Evidence Act 1871 which is a law Consolidating, defining and amending the law of evidence, noprovision of which is challenged as violating the Constitution permits relevancy as the only test of admissibility of evidence  See section 5 of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence Act s5: relevancy only test; no constitutional exclusion like Art20(3); precedents MP Sharma, Kuruma v Queen, English common law.

holdings.text: No writ of prohibition to restrain use of information from illegal search as evidence admissible.

anchor.surface_text: the only question is whether the information gathered as a result of such search and seizure could be used in evidence if it be held that the search and seizure was illegal... We have held that such information can be used.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly dismissed; Delhi HC assumed illegal but denied prohibition; relevancy governs admissibility.

holdings.text: Director of Inspection capable of forming reasonable belief under s132(1) due to oversight powers.

anchor.surface_text: in our opinions there is nosubstance in this argument. The Director of Inspection, as already seen in section 116 of the Income-tax Act, is an officer in the Income-tax Department next only in authority to the Board of Direct Taxes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Powers under ss116-120,135; access to info from ITOs, IACs; subordinates report to him.

holdings.text: Reasonable belief under s132(1)(b) possible without prior summons failure, based on reliable info of concealment.

anchor.surface_text: There is nosubstance, therefore, in the contention that sub-clause b has over-reached itself. The argument that section 132 5 is confiscatory in its effect has also noforce.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustration: honest assessee on paper but secret investments; risk of destruction if summoned.

holdings.text: Searches and seizures in all cases conducted in accordance with s132 and rule 112; no illegality or mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, therefore, we are not inclined to hold that the search and seizure in this Writ Petition was vitiated by any illegality. Writ Petition No. 96 of 1972 The position in this Writ Petition is not different.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchas respectable; allegations denied/afterthought; latitude in seizing documents; grounds for belief satisfied; no oppression.

holdings.text: Specific searches in Pooran Mal (WP 446/71) and Ganeriwala (WP 86/72) not vitiated by illegality or mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: The search and seizure, therefore, impugned in this Writ Petition cannot be regarded as illegal. In the result the two Writ Petitions and the two appeals are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Denial of mala fides allegations; cooperation chart shows non-cooperation; recorded grounds justify belief; assets undisclosed.

holdings.text: Writ petitions and civil appeals dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In M. P. Sharma v. Satish Chandra .  the challenge to the power of issuing a search warrant under section 96  1  as violative of Article 19  1   f  was repelled on the ground that a power of search and seizure is in  1  1954 S.C.R. 1077.

precedents.case_name: M. P. Sharma v. Satish Chandra
precedents.cited_proposition: Power of search and seizure is an overriding power of the State for protection of social security, regulated by law, and does not violate Article 19(1)(f); it is a temporary interference.
precedents.cited_holding: A search and seizure is, therefore, only a temporary interference with the right to hold the premises searched and the articles seized. Statutory regulation in this behalf is necessary and reasonable restriction cannot per se. be companysidered to be unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Commercial Taxes and others v. R. S. Jhaver and others 1 . In that case section 41 of the Madras General Sales Tax Act of 1969 was. under challenge. It was held by this Court that an officer empowered by the Government under sub-section  1  of section 41 was entitled to effect a search and seize goods and articles as provided in that section. 1  19681  1  S.C.R. 148

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Commercial Taxes v. R. S. Jhaver
precedents.cited_proposition: Search and seizure powers in taxing statutes are valid if accompanied by safeguards similar to CrPC, to check tax evasion.
precedents.cited_holding: the power to search under sub-s.  2  is number arbitrary... safeguards provided in S. 165 also apply to searches made under sub-s.  2 .
